content: The [Nixon Nitration Works disaster](/wiki/1924_Nixon_Nitration_Works_disaster "1924 Nixon Nitration Works disaster"), an explosion of [ammonium nitrate](/wiki/Ammonium_nitrate "Ammonium nitrate"), killed at least 18 people, destroyed several miles of [New Jersey](/wiki/New_Jersey "New Jersey") factories, and demolished the "tiny industrial town of [Nixon, New Jersey](/wiki/Nixon,_New_Jersey "Nixon, New Jersey")."
sources: "Blast Levels a Town: TNT, Being Changed to Fertilizer, Blows Up, Killing 18". *[Weekly Kansas City Star](/wiki/Kansas_City_Star "Kansas City Star")*. March 5, 1924. p. 2.

content: Public vehicles such as [taxicabs](/wiki/Taxicab "Taxicab") were allowed into London's [Hyde Park](/wiki/Hyde_Park,_London "Hyde Park, London") for the first time since 1636, after the House of Commons had repealed the ban on motion by M.P. [Ben Smith](/wiki/Ben_Smith_(Labour_politician) "Ben Smith (Labour politician)"). The 1636 law had made Hyde Park "reserved for people who kept their own carriages." Smith himself had been a taxicab driver prior to becoming an official in the Transport and General Workers' Union.
sources: Mercer, Derrik (1989). *Chronicle of the 20th Century*. London: Chronicle Communications Ltd. pp. 316–317. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-582-03919-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3 "Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3").

content: The [Communist Party of Germany](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Germany "Communist Party of Germany") was legally reinstated. It had been banned in November 1923 after it tried to launch a [general strike](/wiki/General_strike "General strike").
sources: [Serge, Victor](/wiki/Victor_Serge "Victor Serge") (2011). *Witness to the German Revolution*. [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"): [Haymarket Books](/wiki/Haymarket_Books "Haymarket Books"). [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-1-60846-172-1](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-60846-172-1 "Special:BookSources/978-1-60846-172-1").

Ceplair, Larry (1987). *Under the Shadow of War: Fascism, Anti-Fascism, and Marxists, 1918–1939*. [New York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"): [Columbia University Press](/wiki/Columbia_University_Press "Columbia University Press"). p. 49. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0-231-06532-9](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-231-06532-9 "Special:BookSources/0-231-06532-9").

content: *[Alice's Day at Sea](/wiki/Alice%27s_Day_at_Sea "Alice's Day at Sea")*, the first of 57 films in [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney")'s [Alice Comedies](/wiki/Alice_Comedies "Alice Comedies") series, was introduced to American cinemas as a short (11-minute) movie to be shown prior to a feature film.[*[unreliable source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Reliable sources")*] The silent film featured 5-year-old [Virginia Davis](/wiki/Virginia_Davis "Virginia Davis") in a combination of live action and animation. An earlier Alice comedy, *[Alice's Wonderland](/wiki/Alice%27s_Wonderland "Alice's Wonderland")*, had been shown to theater owners but never released to the public.
sources: ["Alice's Day at Sea"](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0014662/?ref_=nv_sr_srsg_0_tt_6_nm_2_q_Alice%27s%2520Day%2520). *[Internet Movie Database](/wiki/Internet_Movie_Database "Internet Movie Database")*.

content: **Born:** [Deke Slayton](/wiki/Deke_Slayton "Deke Slayton"), U.S. astronaut who was one of the original [Mercury 7](/wiki/Mercury_7 "Mercury 7") and who later served on the [Apollo–Soyuz](/wiki/Apollo%E2%80%93Soyuz "Apollo–Soyuz") mission in 1975; in [Sparta, Wisconsin](/wiki/Sparta,_Wisconsin "Sparta, Wisconsin") (d. 1993)
sources: Gray, Tara (1999). ["40th Anniversary of Mercury 7: Donald K. "Deke" Slayton"](https://history.nasa.gov/40thmerc7/slayton.htm). *NASA History Program Office*. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20201115205713/https://history.nasa.gov/40thmerc7/slayton.htm) from the original on November 15, 2020. Retrieved September 13, 2023.

	* [Gopinath Saha](/wiki/Gopinath_Saha "Gopinath Saha"), 18, Bengali activist for independence in [British India](/wiki/British_India "British India"), was hanged at the [Alipore Central Jail](/wiki/Alipore_Jail "Alipore Jail") in [Calcutta](/wiki/Calcutta "Calcutta") for the murder of a bystander during his attempt to assassinate Calcutta Police Commissioner [Charles Tegart](/wiki/Charles_Tegart "Charles Tegart").

sources: Sheean, Vincent (March 3, 1924). "Cardinal Asks Belgian Women to Ban Silk Hose". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 10.

content: The [Turkish National Assembly](/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey "Grand National Assembly of Turkey") formally ended the [Ottoman Caliphate](/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate "Ottoman Caliphate") that had operated for 407 years, voting "almost unanimously" to abolish the office, and ordered that [Abdulmejid II](/wiki/Abdulmejid_II "Abdulmejid II") and his harem were to be deported by March 15. Abdulmejid, first cousin of the last Ottoman Sultan [Mehmed VI](/wiki/Mehmed_VI "Mehmed VI"), who had become religious leader of Islam upon being elected Caliph on November 19, was formally deposed at 2:00 the next morning.
sources: "People's Party of Turkey Votes to Banish Caliphate". *[Los Angeles Evening Express](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Evening_Express "Los Angeles Evening Express")*. [AP](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press"). March 3, 1924. p. 18.
"Turkey Votes to Depose Caliph; Harem Packs Up". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 4, 1924. p. 5.

content: [Seán O'Casey](/wiki/Se%C3%A1n_O%27Casey "Seán O'Casey")'s drama *[Juno and the Paycock](/wiki/Juno_and_the_Paycock "Juno and the Paycock")* opened at the [Abbey Theatre](/wiki/Abbey_Theatre "Abbey Theatre"), [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin").
sources: ["Juno and the Paycock"](http://www.irishplayography.com/play.aspx?playid=2077). *PlayographyIreland*. [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin"): Irish Theatre Institute. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

A 7.1 magnitude earthquake, with an epicenter at [Orotina](/wiki/Orotina "Orotina") in [Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica"), struck at 5:23 in the morning local time and killed 70 people. Damage was caused in the capital at [San Jose](/wiki/San_Jose,_Costa_Rica "San Jose, Costa Rica"), 40 miles (64 km) away.
sources: "Costa Rican Capital Wrecked by Earthquake, Lives Lost— Half of San Jose Buildings Damaged in Shocks". *[Washington Evening Star](/wiki/Washington_Evening_Star "Washington Evening Star")*. March 4, 1924. p. 1.
Baker, Garland M. (October 12, 2009). ["Preparation lacking for those inevitable earthquakes"](http://www.amcostarica.com/101209.htm). *A.M. Costa Rica*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: [Aidan de Brune](/wiki/Aidan_de_Brune "Aidan de Brune") became the first person to walk all the way around [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), returning to [Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne") from whence he had departed on September 20, 1921.
sources: Choat, Colin (2018). *The Amateur Tramp: A Walk of Ten Thousand Miles Around Australia*. [Project Gutenberg](/wiki/Project_Gutenberg "Project Gutenberg"). p. 18.

content: The [University of North Carolina Tar Heels](/wiki/1923%E2%80%9324_North_Carolina_Tar_Heels_men%27s_basketball_team "1923–24 North Carolina Tar Heels men's basketball team") men's basketball team completed a perfect season of 26 wins and no losses, as one of the major unbeaten team in the nation, by winning the 16-team [Southern Intercollegiate Conference](/wiki/1924_Southern_Conference_men%27s_basketball_tournament "1924 Southern Conference men's basketball tournament") postseason tournament, defeating the Alabama Crimson Tide, 26 to 18, in [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"). The University of Texas Longhorns also went unbeaten, finishing the Southwest Conference regular season with a 23-0 record and being 20-0 in SWC games, but did not play against North Carolina.
sources: "Carolina Gallops to S. I. C. Championship— They Trounce Alabama, 26–18". *[Atlanta Constitution](/wiki/Atlanta_Constitution "Atlanta Constitution")*. March 5, 1924. p. 9.

	* [Donald R. Yennie](/wiki/Donald_R._Yennie "Donald R. Yennie"), American theoretical physicist known for devising the [Yennie gauge](/wiki/Gauge_fixing#Rξ_gauges "Gauge fixing") mathematical procedure; in [Paterson, New Jersey](/wiki/Paterson,_New_Jersey "Paterson, New Jersey") (d. 1993)

In an elaborate nighttime ceremony at [Luxor](/wiki/Luxor "Luxor") under [floodlights](/wiki/Floodlight "Floodlight"), [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt")'s Prime Minister [Saad Zaghloul](/wiki/Saad_Zaghloul "Saad Zaghloul") formally opened the site of Tutankamun's tomb to the Egyptian public, which reportedly attracted the largest crowd seen in Luxor. The reopening turned into an anti-British demonstration when the British High Commissioner, Field Marshal Allenby, arrived when the crowd was demanding immediate British withdrawal from Egypt.
sources: "Egyptians Reopen Tomb of Pharaoh; Ceremonies Become the Occasion for Frenzied Nationalist Demonstration". [The New York Times Company](/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Company "The New York Times Company"). March 7, 1924. p. 4.

content: [Turkey's first government was reorganized](/wiki/2nd_government_of_Turkey "2nd government of Turkey") as Prime Minister [Ismet Pasha](/wiki/%C4%B0smet_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC "İsmet İnönü") formed a new council of ministers at the request of President Mustapha Kemal Ataturk. Ismet replaced four members of his Cabinet and eliminated the Ministry of Sharia and Foundations, and the Ministry of the General Staff while splitting the Ministry of the Economy into the new Ministry of Commerce and Ministry of Agriculture.
sources: "Turkish Premier Quits— President Asks Him to Form Another Cabinet". *[Philadelphia Inquirer](/wiki/Philadelphia_Inquirer "Philadelphia Inquirer")*. March 7, 1924. p. 3.

content: **Born:** [Obi James Anyasi II](/wiki/Idumuje-Unor#Obi_James_Anyasi_II "Idumuje-Unor"), African tribal monarch who ruled the [Esan people](/wiki/Esan_people "Esan people") of [Idumuje-Unor](/wiki/Idumuje-Unor "Idumuje-Unor") in southeast [Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria "Nigeria") from 1946 to 2013 (d. 2013)

The *Delahueristas*, rebel supporters of former Mexican President [Adolfo de la Huerta](/wiki/Adolfo_de_la_Huerta "Adolfo de la Huerta"), surrendered across Mexico as President [Álvaro Obregón](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Obreg%C3%B3n "Álvaro Obregón") offered an amnesty, bringing an end to the [De la Huerta rebellion](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Obreg%C3%B3n#De_la_Huerta_rebellion,_1923–1924 "Álvaro Obregón") after three months.
sources: "Mexican Revolt Ends as Obregon Offers Amnesty". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 8, 1924. p. 5.

content: A representative of the [Irish Republican Army Organisation](/wiki/Irish_Republican_Army_Organisation "Irish Republican Army Organisation") (IRAO) handed an ultimatum to Ireland's President [W. T. Cosgrave](/wiki/W._T._Cosgrave "W. T. Cosgrave"), from Major-General [Liam Tobin](/wiki/Liam_Tobin "Liam Tobin") and Colonel Charles Dalton, demanding an end to Defence Minister [Richard Mulcahy](/wiki/Richard_Mulcahy "Richard Mulcahy")'s demobilization of Irish Army troops. Mulcahy ordered the arrest of both officers [on charges of mutiny](/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny "Irish Army Mutiny").
sources: Valiulis, Maryann Gialanella (1992). [*Portrait of a Revolutionary: General Richard Mulcahy and the Founding of the Irish Free State*](https://books.google.com/books?id=YGizfkDzVXEC&q=frank+thornton+tom+cullen+mutiny&pg=PA202). [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0813117917](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0813117917 "Special:BookSources/0813117917").

content: **Born:** [Kōbō Abe](/wiki/K%C5%8Db%C5%8D_Abe "Kōbō Abe"), Japanese novelist; in [Kita, Tokyo](/wiki/Kita,_Tokyo "Kita, Tokyo") (d. 1993)

**Died:** [Pat Moran](/wiki/Pat_Moran "Pat Moran"), 48, American baseball player from 1901 to 1914, manager of the Cincinnati Reds in 1922 and 1923, died of kidney disease during spring training in Florida while preparing for the 1924 National League season.

All 171 miners were killed in two explosions at the [Castle Gate mine](/wiki/Castle_Gate_Mine_disaster "Castle Gate Mine disaster") at [Castle Gate, Utah](/wiki/Castle_Gate,_Utah "Castle Gate, Utah"), near the town of [Helper](/wiki/Helper,_Utah "Helper, Utah").
sources: ["1924: Castle Gate Mine Explosion"](http://ilovehistory.utah.gov/time/stories/castle_gate.html). *Utah Division of State History*. [State of Utah](/wiki/Utah "Utah"). Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: The Governor-General of British India, [Lord Reading](/wiki/Rufus_Isaacs,_1st_Marquess_of_Reading "Rufus Isaacs, 1st Marquess of Reading") transferred full power of administration of the [princely state](/wiki/Princely_state "Princely state") of [Bahawalpur](/wiki/Bahawalpur_(princely_state) "Bahawalpur (princely state)") (now part of the Punjab province of Pakistan) to the 19-year-old [Nawab](/wiki/Nawab "Nawab") of Bahawalpur, [Sadeq Mohammad Khan V](/wiki/Sadeq_Mohammad_Khan_V "Sadeq Mohammad Khan V") who had been the nominal ruler since ascending the throne at the age of two on February 15, 1907. Sadeq would remain in power until 1955, when Pakistan abolished its princely states.
sources: ["Nawab Sadiq Muhammad Khan V"](https://web.archive.org/web/20190328043424/https://storyofpakistan.com/nawab-sadiq-muhammad-khan-v). *Story of Pakistan website*. 24 May 2012. Archived from [the original](https://storyofpakistan.com/nawab-sadiq-muhammad-khan-v) on 28 March 2019. Retrieved 18 August 2022.

content: Inventor [Nikola Tesla](/wiki/Nikola_Tesla "Nikola Tesla") spoke out for the first time in years, announcing he had perfected a system of transmitting power without wires.
sources: "Tesla Invents Plan to Transmit Power by Wireless System". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 9, 1924. p. 5.

content: [Georgios Kafantaris](/wiki/Georgios_Kafantaris "Georgios Kafantaris") was forced by the Greek Army to resign as [Prime Minister of Greece](/wiki/List_of_prime_ministers_of_Greece "List of prime ministers of Greece"), along with his cabinet, less than a month after succeeding [Eleftherios Venizelos](/wiki/Eleftherios_Venizelos "Eleftherios Venizelos"), after refusing to endorse the Army's call for the abolition of the monarchy in favor of a republic. Kafantaris had proposed a referendum on the future of the monarchy while the Army requested an immediate change.
sources: "Cabinet of Greece Resigns Under Fire". *[San Francisco Examiner](/wiki/San_Francisco_Examiner "San Francisco Examiner")*. March 8, 1924. p. 16.

content: The Kingdom of Greece established diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, a policy that continued even after the kingdom was abolished less than one month later.

sources: ["A. H. Smith Killed by Fall From Horse"](https://www.nytimes.com/1924/03/09/archives/woman-rider-in-his-path-reining-in-suddenly-famous-railroad-man.html). *The New York Times*. March 9, 1924. p. 21.

content: The French Cabinet held an emergency meeting to consider extraordinary measures to stabilize the collapsing [franc](/wiki/French_franc "French franc"), which dropped to 117.60 francs against the British [pound sterling](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling").
sources: Wales, Henry (March 10, 1924). "French Rulers Plan Desperate Aid to Francs". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 2.

content: **Died:** General [Panagiotis Danglis](/wiki/Panagiotis_Danglis "Panagiotis Danglis"), 70, former Greek Army leader and Minister of Military Affairs during World War One, co-inventor of the Schneider-Danglis mountain gun

[U.S. Secretary of the Navy](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Navy "United States Secretary of the Navy") [Edwin Denby](/wiki/Edwin_Denby_(politician) "Edwin Denby (politician)") resigned over the [Teapot Dome scandal](/wiki/Teapot_Dome_scandal "Teapot Dome scandal"). He said that by quitting before he could be asked to resign, he was "dying with my face toward the enemy."
sources: Henning, Arthur Sears (March 11, 1924). "Gusher of Oil Bubbles Up in Senate Derrick". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: France obtained a $50 million credit from American banks and a £5 million credit from London to stabilize the franc.
sources: "France Obtains $50,000,000 to Bolster Franc". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 11, 1924. p. 1.
Steele, John (March 12, 1924). "British Pledge $21,500,000 Aid to Help Save Falling Franc". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*: 3.

content: In the case of *Radice v. New York*, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld a [New York](/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)") state statute banning late-night working for women on grounds of health.
sources: ["Radice v. New York"](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/264/292/). *[US Supreme Court](/wiki/US_Supreme_Court "US Supreme Court")*. Justia. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

sources: "Honduran Dictator Gutierrez Is Dead; He Fled From Tegucigalpa, Trying to Come Here for Insulin Treatment". *The New York Times*. p. 13.

content: The worst Atlantic gale in twenty years hit the [east coast of the United States](/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the United States"), downing telephone and telegraph lines and killing nine people.
sources: "Worst Gale in Years batters East; 9 Killed". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 12, 1924. p. 3.

content: [Belva Gaertner](/wiki/Belva_Gaertner "Belva Gaertner"), a cabaret singer, was arrested for the murder of her abusive lover, Walter Law, who was found dead from a bullet wound in her car in Chicago. She would be acquitted based on reasonable doubt over whether Law's death was a murder or a suicide. The story would be the inspiration of the [Maurine Dallas Watkins](/wiki/Maurine_Dallas_Watkins "Maurine Dallas Watkins") Broadway play, *[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago_(play) "Chicago (play)")* in 1926, and for the successful [John Kander](/wiki/John_Kander "John Kander") and [Fred Ebb](/wiki/Fred_Ebb "Fred Ebb") [musical](/wiki/Musical_theatre "Musical theatre") *[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago_(musical) "Chicago (musical)")* in 1975.
sources: Pauly, Thomas H., ed. (1997). *Chicago: With the Chicago Tribune Articles that Inspired It*. [Southern Illinois University](/wiki/Southern_Illinois_University "Southern Illinois University").

content: [Adolfo de la Huerta](/wiki/Adolfo_de_la_Huerta "Adolfo de la Huerta"), leader of the failed Mexican rebellion against President [Álvaro Obregón](/wiki/%C3%81lvaro_Obreg%C3%B3n "Álvaro Obregón"), went into exile to Florida.
sources: ["Mexico (1906–present)"](http://uca.edu/politicalscience/dadm-project/western-hemisphere-region/mexico-1906–present/). *[University of Central Arkansas](/wiki/University_of_Central_Arkansas "University of Central Arkansas")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: [Commonwealth Oil Refineries](/wiki/Commonwealth_Oil_Refineries "Commonwealth Oil Refineries"), a joint venture of the Australian government and the [Anglo-Persian Oil Company](/wiki/Anglo-Persian_Oil_Company "Anglo-Persian Oil Company") and the first oil refinery in [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), began its refining operations as it received its first shipment of crude oil at [Laverton, Victoria](/wiki/Laverton,_Victoria "Laverton, Victoria"), north of [Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne").

The World Court of the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") issued its decision to end the [border dispute between Poland and Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Czechoslovak_border_conflicts "Polish–Czechoslovak border conflicts") within the [Orava Territory](/wiki/%C3%81rva_County "Árva County") in a reworking of the original Spa Conference of 1920 decision. Czechoslovakia was allowed to retain [Javorina](/wiki/Javorina "Javorina") (formerly Javorzyna) and [Ždiar](/wiki/%C5%BDdiar "Ždiar") in return for ceding Nižná Lipnica (now [Lipnica Wielka, Nowy Targ County](/wiki/Lipnica_Wielka,_Nowy_Targ_County "Lipnica Wielka, Nowy Targ County")) to Poland, while Polish territory around Sucha Góra and Glodōvka became [Suchá Hora](/wiki/Such%C3%A1_Hora "Suchá Hora") and [Hladovka](/wiki/Hladovka "Hladovka") in what is now [Slovakia](/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia").
sources: [Osmańczyk, Edmund Jan](/wiki/Edmund_Osma%C5%84czyk "Edmund Osmańczyk"); Mango, Anthony, eds. (2003). "Javorzyna". *Encyclopedia of the United Nations and International Agreements*. [Taylor & Francis](/wiki/Taylor_%26_Francis "Taylor & Francis"). p. 1199.

A [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") committee spearheaded by American diplomat [Norman Davis](/wiki/Norman_Davis_(diplomat) "Norman Davis (diplomat)") reached a settlement on the question of the administration of the [Klaipėda Region](/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region "Klaipėda Region") (*Memelland* in German), leading to the signing of the [Klaipėda Convention](/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Convention "Klaipėda Convention") two months later.
sources: "Yankee Settles Memel Issue". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 15, 1924. p. 7.

content: Fighting broke out in [Honduras](/wiki/Honduras "Honduras") in the wake of the death of President [Rafael López Gutiérrez](/wiki/Rafael_L%C3%B3pez_Guti%C3%A9rrez "Rafael López Gutiérrez"), initiated by rebels who opposed the new President, [Francisco Bueso](/wiki/Francisco_Bueso "Francisco Bueso").
sources: "Rebels Put New Honduran Rule to Wild Flight". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 20, 1924. p. 13.

[Voting was held in the Dominican Republic](/wiki/1924_Dominican_Republic_general_election "1924 Dominican Republic general election") for the next president and for the bicameral [Congress](/wiki/Congress_of_the_Dominican_Republic "Congress of the Dominican Republic").[Horacio Vásquez](/wiki/Horacio_V%C3%A1squez "Horacio Vásquez") defeated [Jacinto Peynado](/wiki/Jacinto_Peynado "Jacinto Peynado") by more than 2 to 1 margin, and his Progressive National Alliance party won 24 of the 31 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 10 of the 12 seats in the Dominican Senate.
[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt")'s [King Fuad I](/wiki/Fuad_I_of_Egypt "Fuad I of Egypt") opened the initial session of the first-ever Egyptian constitutional parliament.

King [Victor Emmanuel III of Italy](/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III_of_Italy "Victor Emmanuel III of Italy") gave the warrior-poet [Gabriele D'Annunzio](/wiki/Gabriele_D%27Annunzio "Gabriele D'Annunzio") the title of Prince of [Montenevoso](/wiki/Sne%C5%BEnik_(mountain) "Snežnik (mountain)").
sources: "Italian King Makes D'Annunzio Prince of Montenevoso". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 16, 1924. p. 5.

content: [England](/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team "England national rugby union team") beat [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_union_team "Scotland national rugby union team"), 19 to 0, to clinch a perfect 4–0 record in the [Five Nations Championship](/wiki/1924_Five_Nations_Championship "1924 Five Nations Championship") rugby tournament and complete a [Grand Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_(rugby_union) "Grand Slam (rugby union)").
[Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya") held a [legislative election](/wiki/1924_Kenyan_legislative_election "1924 Kenyan legislative election"), the first under its new Constitution.

Italy formally annexed [Fiume](/wiki/Fiume "Fiume") in a colorful ceremony. Crowds cheered as King [Victor Emmanuel III](/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III "Victor Emmanuel III") read the annexation decree.

content: [Eligio Ayala](/wiki/Eligio_Ayala "Eligio Ayala") resigned as [President of Paraguay](/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_Paraguay "List of heads of state of Paraguay") 13 months after he had been appointed by the Paraguayan Congress on April 12, 1923. He was replaced by [Luis Alberto Riart](/wiki/Luis_Alberto_Riart "Luis Alberto Riart"), who was selected by the Congress.

The [Irish Army Mutiny](/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny "Irish Army Mutiny") came to a crisis as 40 armed soldiers assembled at a hotel in Dublin to plan the next move, including [a possible coup d'etat](/wiki/Irish_Army_Mutiny "Irish Army Mutiny") against the Irish government. Two truckloads of Irish Army troops surrounded the building and a standoff ensued. The Irish government responded by getting the resignation of the Irish Army Council members, along with that of Defence Minister [Richard Mulcahy](/wiki/Richard_Mulcahy "Richard Mulcahy").

The swashbuckling film *[The Thief of Bagdad](/wiki/The_Thief_of_Bagdad_(1924_film) "The Thief of Bagdad (1924 film)")*, starring [Douglas Fairbanks](/wiki/Douglas_Fairbanks "Douglas Fairbanks"), was released.
sources: Mercer, Derrik (1989). *Chronicle of the 20th Century*. London: Chronicle Communications Ltd. pp. 316–317. [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [978-0-582-03919-3](/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3 "Special:BookSources/978-0-582-03919-3").

[Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill") of the [Constitutionalists](/wiki/Constitutionalist_(UK) "Constitutionalist (UK)") lost the [Westminster Abbey by-election](/wiki/1924_Westminster_Abbey_by-election "1924 Westminster Abbey by-election") by 43 votes to [Unionist](/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK) "Conservative Party (UK)") candidate [Otho Nicholson](/wiki/Otho_Nicholson "Otho Nicholson"), who had 8,187 votes to Churchill's 8,144. Churchill had originally lost by 33 votes and requested a recount, which showed a larger winning majority.
sources: [Jenkins, Roy](/wiki/Roy_Jenkins "Roy Jenkins"). *Churchill: A Biography*.

content: The "Eugenical Sterilization Act" went into effect in the U.S. state of [Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia") upon being signed into law by Governor [E. Lee Trinkle](/wiki/E._Lee_Trinkle "E. Lee Trinkle"), providing for the sterilization of persons in mental institutions.
sources: Noll, Steven (2018). *Feeble-Minded in Our Midst: Institutions for the Mentally Retarded in the South, 1900-1940*. [University of North Carolina Press](/wiki/University_of_North_Carolina_Press "University of North Carolina Press").

content: [Nadir of American race relations](/wiki/Nadir_of_American_race_relations "Nadir of American race relations"): In the U.S., the [Virginia General Assembly](/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly "Virginia General Assembly") passed the [Racial Integrity Act](/wiki/Racial_Integrity_Act_of_1924 "Racial Integrity Act of 1924"), amending the state's racial classification law which had provided that a person was considered to be "colored" if they had a great-grandparent who was African-American. The amendment enacted the "[one-drop rule](/wiki/One-drop_rule "One-drop rule")", which provided that a person was considered non-white if it was shown that they had *any* ancestor who was African-American. The 1924 Act had what was called the "Pocahontas Clause" providing that a person with an American Indian ancestor would be considered white if they were 15/16ths European.
sources: [Floyd, Jami](/wiki/Jami_Floyd "Jami Floyd") (February 10, 2011). ["Opinion: Why One Drop Matters"](http://www.wnyc.org/story/114026-why-one-drop-matters/). *[WNYC](/wiki/WNYC "WNYC")*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: A British soldier was killed, and 21 others wounded, in a drive-by shooting at [Queenstown](/wiki/Cobh "Cobh") in Ireland's [County Cork](/wiki/County_Cork "County Cork"). Four IRA members dressed as [Irish Free State Army](/wiki/National_Army_(Ireland) "National Army (Ireland)") officers drove into town in a converted 1919 Rolls-Royce, dubbed the "[Moon Car](/wiki/Moon_Car "Moon Car")". As the Moon Car drove past the destroyer [HMS *Scythe*](/wiki/HMS_Scythe_(1918) "HMS Scythe (1918)") at the port of [Spike Island](/wiki/Spike_Island,_County_Cork "Spike Island, County Cork"), the men opened fire with a machine gun.
sources: Clothier, John. ["The Moon Car"](http://www.rrec.org.uk/Cars/Rolls-Royce_Armoured_Cars/Armoured_Cars_in_Action.php#_The_Moon_Car:). *Rolls-Royce Enthusiasts Club*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

content: London drivers of [trams](/wiki/Tram "Tram") and public buses went on strike.

content: Boxer [Abe Goldstein](/wiki/Abe_Goldstein "Abe Goldstein") won the world bantamweight championship in a 15-round bout against [Joe Lynch](/wiki/Joe_Lynch_(boxer) "Joe Lynch (boxer)") before 14,900 people at [Madison Square Garden](/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1890) "Madison Square Garden (1890)") in New York City.
sources: ["Abe Goldstein Beats Joe Lynch for Title; Wins World's Bantamweight Championship in 15-Round Decision Bout at Garden"](https://www.nytimes.com/1924/03/22/archives/abe-goldstein-beats-joe-lynch-for-title-wins-worlds-bantamweight.html). *The New York Times*. March 22, 1924. p. 10.

**Died:** [T. E. Dunville](/wiki/T._E._Dunville "T. E. Dunville") (stage name for Thomas Edward Wallen), 56, English comedian, committed suicide one day after his final stage performance. He left a suicide note for his wife, and his body was found in the [River Thames](/wiki/River_Thames "River Thames") the next day.
sources: "Tragic End of Lost Comedian— T. E. Dunville Found Drowned Near Old Home". *[Daily Mirror](/wiki/Daily_Mirror "Daily Mirror")*. March 24, 1924. p. 2.

content: The ocean liner [RMS *Olympic*](/wiki/RMS_Olympic "RMS Olympic") collided with the smaller liner *[Fort St George](/wiki/HMAT_Wandilla "HMAT Wandilla")* in New York City. The damage required repairs to the extent of which had never been attempted on a ship the size of *Olympic* before.
sources: Goossens, Reuben. ["RMS Olympic"](http://www.ssmaritime.com/RMS-Olympic.htm). *SS Maritime*. Retrieved January 16, 2015.

French [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_France "Prime Minister of France") [Raymond Poincaré](/wiki/Raymond_Poincar%C3%A9 "Raymond Poincaré") resigned after his government was defeated in the [Chamber of Deputies](/wiki/Chamber_of_Deputies_(France) "Chamber of Deputies (France)") by a vote of 271 to 264. The confidence vote was a complete surprise and Poincaré was not even present, as he was in a committee meeting when it was announced and voted on.
sources: Wales, Henry (March 27, 1924). "Poincaré to Take Reins of France Again". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: [Friedrich Akel](/wiki/Friedrich_Akel "Friedrich Akel") became the new [*Rigivanem*](/wiki/State_Elder_of_Estonia "State Elder of Estonia") (literally the "State Elder"), the head of state and head of government for [Estonia](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia"), after [Konstantin Päts](/wiki/Konstantin_P%C3%A4ts "Konstantin Päts") had announced his resignation on March 11.
Over 100 people died in landslides around [Amalfi](/wiki/Amalfi "Amalfi") in Italy.
sources: "Landslides Kill 73 in Italy; Rush to Rescue Yanks". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. March 27, 1924. p. 1.
"Landslide at Beauty Spot of Italy Kills Hundred". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*: 3. March 28, 1924.

content: The opening of the first elected parliament in the [Kingdom of Iraq](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Iraq "Kingdom of Iraq"), the 100-member Constituent Assembly, was opened in Baghdad by [King Faisal I](/wiki/Faisal_I_of_Iraq "Faisal I of Iraq") and directed to draw up the Middle Eastern nation's [first constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Iraq#History "Constitution of Iraq"), which would be ratified in 1925.
sources: Al-Wardi, Ali (1976). *Social Aspects of Iraq's Modern History*. AlWarraq Press. pp. 270–300.

content: [Raymond Poincaré](/wiki/Raymond_Poincar%C3%A9 "Raymond Poincaré") accepted President [Alexandre Millerand](/wiki/Alexandre_Millerand "Alexandre Millerand")'s request to form a new government.
sources: Wales, Henry (March 27, 1924). "Poincaré to Take Reins of France Again". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 1.

content: [Erich Ludendorff](/wiki/Erich_Ludendorff "Erich Ludendorff") and [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") made their final addresses as their trial for treason wound down in [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich").
sources: [Childers, Thomas](/wiki/Thomas_Childers "Thomas Childers") (1983). [*The Nazi Voter: The Social Foundations of Fascism in Germany, 1919–1933*](https://archive.org/details/nazivotersocialf0000chil/page/57). University of North Carolina Press. p. [57](https://archive.org/details/nazivotersocialf0000chil/page/57). [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier) "ISBN (identifier)") [0-8078-1570-5](/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-8078-1570-5 "Special:BookSources/0-8078-1570-5") – via Internet Archive.

content: The [New York Philharmonic](/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic "New York Philharmonic") orchestra began its tradition of the [Young People's Concerts](/wiki/Young_People%27s_Concerts "Young People's Concerts"), with guest conductor [Ernest Schelling](/wiki/Ernest_Schelling "Ernest Schelling") providing a description of aspects to be listened for in the music that would be heard, or about the parts of the orchestra itself. From 1926 onward, a concert would be performed every month.

*[Irrelohe](/wiki/Irrelohe "Irrelohe")*, a three-act [opera](/wiki/Opera "Opera") by German composer [Franz Schreker](/wiki/Franz_Schreker "Franz Schreker") premiered at the [Stadttheater Köln](/wiki/Cologne_Opera "Cologne Opera") in [Köln](/wiki/Cologne "Cologne"), with [Otto Klemperer](/wiki/Otto_Klemperer "Otto Klemperer") as conductor. *Irrelohe*, [German](/wiki/German_language "German language") for a crazy fire, was named by Schreker for the [Irrenlohe station](/wiki/Irrenlohe_station "Irrenlohe station"), a railway stop in Bavaria.
sources: Hailey, Christopher (1993). *Franz Schreker, 1878–1934: A cultural biography*. [Cambridge University Press](/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press "Cambridge University Press").

content: [Total S.A.](/wiki/Total_S.A. "Total S.A."), one of the major energy product and sales companies worldwide, was founded in [France](/wiki/France "France"), as predecessor name was Campagnie Francaise des Petroles.

content: The [Grand National horse race](/wiki/1924_Grand_National "1924 Grand National") at Aintree Racecourse in England was won by Master Robert, a 25 to 1 long shot, ridden by Bob Trudgill and trained by Aubrey Hastings.

The first known [Motocross](/wiki/Motocross "Motocross") in the United Kingdom took place at [Camberley](/wiki/Camberley "Camberley"), [Surrey](/wiki/Surrey "Surrey"), with a "[scramble race](/wiki/Hare_scramble "Hare scramble")" of 89 riders, rather than the individual time trials that had been staged by clubs. Rather than everyone starting at once, however, riders started once per minute, riding two laps on a challenging course 25 miles (40 km) long.
sources: Woods, Bob (2008). *Motocross History: From Local Scrambling to World Championship MX to Freestyle*. Crabtree Publishing. p. 12.

content: The popular [musical](/wiki/Musical_theatre "Musical theatre") *[Wildflower](/wiki/Wildflower_(musical) "Wildflower (musical)")*, with music by [Herbert Stothart](/wiki/Herbert_Stothart "Herbert Stothart") and [Vincent Youmans](/wiki/Vincent_Youmans "Vincent Youmans"), and lyrics by [Oscar Hammerstein II](/wiki/Oscar_Hammerstein_II "Oscar Hammerstein II") and [Otto Harbach](/wiki/Otto_Harbach "Otto Harbach"), closed at the [Casino Theatre](/wiki/Casino_Theatre_(New_York_City) "Casino Theatre (New York City)") on [Broadway](/wiki/Broadway_theatre "Broadway theatre") after 477 performances, following its premiere on February 7, 1923.
sources: [Mantle, Burns](/wiki/Burns_Mantle "Burns Mantle") (1923). *The Best Plays of 1922–1923*. Small, Maynard and Co. p. 529.

content: Jews in [Bucharest](/wiki/Bucharest "Bucharest") in [Romania](/wiki/Romania "Romania") were targeted by rioters in nighttime attacks that continued into the next morning.
sources: Fendrick, Raymond (March 31, 1924). "Stones for Jews, Cheers for Ford in Bucharest". *[Chicago Daily Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Daily_Tribune "Chicago Daily Tribune")*. p. 12.

The first radio broadcaster in the German state of [Bavaria](/wiki/Bavaria "Bavaria"), [Bayerischer Rundfunk](/wiki/Bayerischer_Rundfunk "Bayerischer Rundfunk"), began broadcasting from Munich at 5:00 in the afternoon under the name "Deutsche Stunde in Bayern".
In the U.S., the drinking of [denatured alcohol](/wiki/Denatured_alcohol "Denatured alcohol") at a party in [Toledo, Ohio](/wiki/Toledo,_Ohio "Toledo, Ohio") killed at least 12 people.

The [German People's Party](/wiki/German_People%27s_Party "German People's Party") announced in its [election platform](/wiki/Party_platform "Party platform") that it stood for a "new democratic monarchy". One of their election slogans was, "We are fighting under the colours of the [black, white and red](/wiki/Flag_of_Germany#North_German_Confederation_and_the_German_Empire_.281866.E2.80.931918.29 "Flag of Germany")".

content: The air transport company [Imperial Airways](/wiki/Imperial_Airways "Imperial Airways") was founded in the United Kingdom by the merger of the UK's four existing airlines, [Handley Page Transport](/wiki/Handley_Page_Transport "Handley Page Transport"), [Instone Air Line](/wiki/Instone_Air_Line "Instone Air Line"), [Daimler Airway](/wiki/Daimler_Airway "Daimler Airway") and [British Marine Air Navigation Co Ltd](/wiki/British_Marine_Air_Navigation_Co_Ltd "British Marine Air Navigation Co Ltd"). The four combined their aircraft for a fleet of 13 planes operating out of [Croydon Airport](/wiki/Croydon_Airport "Croydon Airport") to serve international flights to and from [London](/wiki/London "London"). In 1939, Imperial would merge with [British Airways Ltd](/wiki/British_Airways_Ltd "British Airways Ltd") to form [British Overseas Airways Corporation](/wiki/British_Overseas_Airways_Corporation "British Overseas Airways Corporation") (BOAC), which would merge in 1974, fifty years from the day of Imperial's founding, with [British European Airways](/wiki/British_European_Airways "British European Airways") to create [British Airways](/wiki/British_Airways "British Airways").
sources: ["Imperial Airways"](https://web.archive.org/web/20071111050826/http://www.century-of-flight.net/Aviation%20history/coming%20of%20age/imperial%20airways.htm). *Century-of-Flight*. Archived from [the original](http://www.century-of-flight.net/Aviation%20history/coming%20of%20age/imperial%20airways.htm) on November 11, 2007.

content: The London tram and bus drivers' strike ended after a vote on a new wage package from the transport companies.
